newsitem.title: HUNGARY: Talks on Alitalia divestment in Malev set to start.
newsitem.headline: Talks on Alitalia divestment in Malev set to start.

text.p: Hungarian officials will travel to Rome on Thursday to start negotiations to repurchase a 30 percent stake in Hungarian airline Magyar Legikozlekedesi Rt (Malev ) that Italian carrier Alitalia bought in 1992, the government said on Thursday.

The annoucement follows the European Commission's decision to clear the payment of 2.75 trillion lire in aid to Alitalia from Italian government. The approval was contingent partly on Alitalia agreeing to sell its stake in Malev.

The negotiations also will likely involve a buy-back of the five percent stake in Malev that Italian agency SIMEST bought at the time of the Alitalia purchase, the Hungarian goverment said at its weekly news conference.
"I would think that these would be handled as one group," government spokesman Elemer Kiss told reports, refering to Alitalia and SIMEST.

The Hungarian government also said that Malev needs to increase its capital by 4.5 billion forints, including $20-25 million in state contributions to be processed by the Hungarian privatisation agency APV Rt, Kiss said.
APV owns 64 percent of Malev, he said.
"Where that money will come from, I cannot say -- it was not discussed," Kiss said in answer to a question.
"After this transaction, strategic investors will be solicited, and negotiations about privatisation will be started," he added.
Hungarian law requires that 25 percent plus one share of Malev equity remains permanently with the Hungarian state, while a total of 50 percent plus one vote of the stock remains in Hungarian hands.
Malev also will seek loans worth $60 million by 2000, Kiss said.
